description: 1748, from French brochure (“stitched work”), from brocher (“to stitch”), from Old French brochier (“to pierce”), from broche (“awl”), from Vulgar Latin brocca, from Latin broccus (“pointy-toothed”). Cognate to broach.

entries.meaning: A booklet of printed informational matter, like a pamphlet, often for promotional purposes.
examples: have a look in the Vans brochure for a new vacuum cleaner
